```{r, include=FALSE} library(htmltools) library(here) source(here("R", "functions.R")) ``` ### {{< fa circle-user >}} Bio :::{.bio-row} :::{.bio-column-right} ```{r out.width='275px', out.extra='style="display:block; margin-left:auto; margin-right:auto; clip-path: circle();"'} #| echo: false knitr::include_graphics("https://raw.githubusercontent.com/AtlasOfLivingAustralia/ala-labs/main/images/people/callum.jpg") ``` ::: :::{.bio-column-left} Callum is an ecological data analyst with a Masters in Quantitative Biology. He has a background in population ecology modelling and is passionate about effective and aesthetic data visualisation. As a data analyst with the ALA, he works on projects that support biosecurity and improve data visualisation using ALA data. ::: ::: :::{.column-body style="margin-top:-20px;"} ```{r} #| echo: false tags$div(class = "row", style = "display: flex;", create_button( icon = "fab fa-github fa-xl", url = "https://github.com/cjwaite23" ) ) ``` ::: ### {{< fa newspaper >}} Posts [Combining multiple species distributions on one map with hexagons and points](https://labs.ala.org.au/posts/2024-01-25_hex_point_maps/)
*Visualising multiple species distributions in a single figure can be difficult if there are areas where ranges overlap. In this post we introduce a way to show several species distributions in an area at once using a novel twist on the commonly used hexbin map.*
